The break statement is used to end prematurely a for, repeat, while or do / until loop of some kind, or to tell a switch statement to end at that point, or to prematurely end a with call. Please see the individual pages for these different functions to get a more in-depth explanation of how it can be used under each circumstance. Note that if break is used outside of any of these contexts it will give an error.
Below you can see a few basic examples of how break can be used, and its syntax is simply:

{ANY_CODE} for (var i = 0; i < 10; i += 1)
{nbsp_x4}{
{nbsp_x4}if (array[i] == 234)
{nbsp_x8}{
{nbsp_x8}break;
{nbsp_x8}}
{nbsp_x4}}
num = i;

{ANY_CODE} var i = 0;
var temp = 0;
repeat (10)
{nbsp_x4}{
{nbsp_x4}temp += array[i];
{nbsp_x4}if (temp > max_total)
{nbsp_x8}{
{nbsp_x8}break;
{nbsp_x8}}
{nbsp_x4}else
{nbsp_x8}{
{nbsp_x8}i += 1;
{nbsp_x8}}
{nbsp_x4}}

{ANY_CODE} var i = 0;
while (!place_free(x, y))
{nbsp_x4}{
{nbsp_x4}x = random(room_width);
{nbsp_x4}y = random(room_height);
{nbsp_x4}if (i > 50)
{nbsp_x8}{
{nbsp_x8}break;
{nbsp_x8}}
{nbsp_x4}else
{nbsp_x8}{
{nbsp_x8}i+=1;
{nbsp_x8}}
{nbsp_x4}}
break in a do / until loop:

{ANY_CODE} var _id = noone;
do
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} _id = list[| 0];
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} if instance_exists(_id)
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} _break;
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} }
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} ds_list_delete(list, 0);
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} }
until (ds_list_empty(list));
target = _id;

{ANY_CODE} switch (keyboard_key)
{nbsp_x4}{
{nbsp_x4}case vk_left:
{nbsp_x4}case ord("A"):
{nbsp_x8}x -= 4;
{nbsp_x8}break;
{nbsp_x4}case vk_right:

{nbsp_x8}x += 4;

{nbsp_x8}y += 4;
{nbsp_x8}break;
